XtIava3uZBd_EMeXRiIJyA.text: The lamb was delicious! It was cooked well and had great flavor. Cooking with chocolate is an interesting take. I also enjoyed the atmosphere of the restaurant.

3mKvHLdBtlEFnQqHFJqsuw.text: Came in to taste chocolate and left with the best coffee we had on our two week trek from London to Naples.  Do NOT walk by without ordering a latte.  Great nuttiness and cute little shop in Borough Market.  Now how can I make it back here for some more???

9fIPxYxD3o2ZuNuPzcp4DA.text: I popped over to Borough Market this afternoon to buy some Jerusalem artichokes for a soup I'm planning to make this weekend (I thought it unwise to rely on our local Sainsburies and Tescos). I was very excited to spot a new chocolate cafe and shop just at the beginning os Stoney Street: Rabot Estate. Apparently, it is the Borough Market 'farm shop' of one of the oldest cocoa estates in St Lucia, dating to 1745. The founder of the Hotel Chocolat chain of shops (and website) bought the Estate a few years ago and have invested heavily in new cocao plants and upgrading equipment and systems. Rabot Estate is taking the lead in reviving the cocoa industry in St Lucia. The shop is pretty eye-catching and completely open to the street. It's decorated in lots of chocolate browns, with reclaimed woods, corrugated iron panels and simple stencil-style typography and manilla labels. However the pricing is anything but basic - £8 for a bag of chocolate anyone? I decided to play to safe and bought myself a small bar of their 'Dash of Milk' range (mid-way between classic dark chocolate and milk chocolate) to try. The 35g bars come in at £2.75 (however if you buy three they come at £2.50 each). At the till I succumbed to temptation and had a hot chocolate (a more reasonable £2.50 per cup). You can choose between a 70% cocoa or a 100% cocoa, which you can sweeten to personal taste. I went for the 70% option. This turned out to be very frothy and light - not particularly thick in texture but with a wonderfully thick chocolate flavour which coated my mouth and lasted a while. I think this might just become a Borough Market tradition for me. They also sell something called 'chocolate tea' which apparently was big in 18th-century London before hot chocolate caught on. I need to try that sometime. Also available are chocolate-themed savoury snacks. This place is a great addition to Borough market.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

Re1M_FCsWyVaiMDL3jPKfg.text: Rabot 1745 is trying to go back to basics to educate people on the cacao nut - its not chocolate, but its the nut that chocolate is made from.  And you can only call it chocolate when at least 4% sugar is added to it (a little tidbit that our waitress told us).  We started off the evening with cacao nut tasting and a short blurb from the waitress on the Ecuadorian nut.  Don't just pop it in your mouth like I did - make sure you crack the outside shell and eat the bean on the inside.  I've seen some TripAdvisor reviews who view the restaurant and stylish and innovative, I personally don't think the innovation side of it was executed that well as a whole.  On their desserts and hot chocolate - sure!  But on the appies + entrees, not so much.  Every single dish on the menu had cacao in it, and I was curious to know how the dishes would be enhanced.  But sadly, it didn't.  And I think the rest of the party felt the same way.  Some dishes were good - but I don't think cacao made a difference.  The beef carpaccio (£9) was good but pricey - 3 slices of beef wrapped around some zesty celeriac and juniper dressing.  I would not recommend the guinea fowl (£20), as it ended up being really dry and bland.  The jus was equally bland - I took a few sips from the little cup.  The fowl was served on an aubergine side which was tasty and tangy, so I had to include a bit of that in each bite.  Out of all the dishes, I think the best one was the roast lamb as it was very tender.  But again, even if the cacao was taken out of all the dishes, I felt that most of the dishes were just mediocre.  Come dessert - it seemed everyone was more interested in the chocolate desserts than the main entrees.  Our server said that the cacao experience is supposed to be more on the educational side, and not necessarily the highlight of their dishes, which will be  changed seasonally.  And while their dishes aren't too adventurous, it is meant to draw patrons to the restaurant - then when Rabot has a stronger reputation and foothold, they will probably branch out to create more adventurous dishes. My highlight of the evening?  The praline hot chocolate for £3.50 is probably the best hot chocolate I've had.  Not crazy sugary sweet, I felt it tasted more like a praline drink with a hint of chocolate.  It was divine!  And this is coming from a person who doesn't regularly eat sweets / dessert or addicted to chocolate.  We bought a pouch of the hot chocolate (£7.50), and while they do have a praline spread, I think there's a jar of Nutella at home that I will stir in.  Maybe I'm not the best person to be reviewing this restaurant, but I found cacao to just be a boring little nut.  It only added texture to the dishes, and didn't enhance anything.  I was wishing that they would have at least tried to make some savoury dishes using chocolate even, and this is coming from someone who's not a huge fan of chocolate.Anyway, the cacao nuts are roasted on site, and batches of chocolate are freshly made here.  But - I think my relationship with the cacao nut will only go as far as chocolate.  I'll come back on a cold day for a nice hot cup of chocolate, but that's it.  On the plus side, the diners all received 20% off on any purchases in their chocolate shop.  This is more of a 2.5 star rating for me.  I don't think I'd come back for the food, as I think I've definitely had better, though the carpaccio was delicious (but small =( )

q9aaYpauqgROXpzn7AEZPA.text: Fantastic chocolates - with a plethora of options and varieties.  They have some unique combinations - cocoa beans dipped in chocolates that they offer to try - even if you dont purchase - you should try it - because it is really different and quite good!  I had a drinking chocolate - instead of a coffee - because well come on its a chocolate place.  The drinking chocolate was really good - but I dont have it very often - so have to volunteer I dont have a lot to compare it against, but I liked the fact that I could taste chocolate flavor and not just a spoonful of sugar.  Definitely a bit pricey - but for handmade chocolates its worth trying once! Only drawback - thinking through treadmill time to compensate.  :)

0I6gODTv-RENn0LQ16ZsgA.text: When visiting Borough Market  & if you're into dark chocolates - you have to go to Rabot Estate (under Hotelchocolat label) for a taste of the BEST dark chocolate in the UK.  Their coffee and desserts are great too.  I'll be back for more soon.

H_t8rayjLJh5ZgvPSjARrg.text: The gingerbread infused chocolate buttons are back!!!!! You gotta go and try them. Sure they are expensive at £5.50 a bag (and sadly not a very large bag) but they literally taste like Christmas in your mouth!

LHXD4PN3cJt40uigoUdFqw.text: You need a mortgage to shop here. Everything looks nice but I don't know if it tastes any good becuase with the proce of a chocolate bar I can do my weekly shop. At Waitrose. With change.And Yes I am bitter, this shop is right on my office doorstep but along with most other retailers in Borough Market I have to avoid it to avoid Bankrupcy.

XlGDZ3OCy9-i1R6zbRZwSw.text: Recommended if you've got money to spend. They've got a huge variety of chocolates, both their own and other high quality brands (e.g. hotel chocolat). There's also a tiny cafe with various chocolate drinks and possibly food, if I remember correctly.

y44iVky3ZLmmPsdg4eFO8w.text: The shop of a St Lucian chocolatiers collective in Borough Market.  If you like your chocolate, this is your place.  By no means cheap, but by no means average.  Great choc, great coffee and remarkably zesty orange sponge, with or without chocolate on top.  This feels like a coco plantation shop rather than a Swiss confectioners, which to a large extent, is because it is.  A very rustic interior selling chocolate by the block as well as truffles and all manner of more-ish delectations.  All over a great place to grab a coffee and munch on some coco-ey loveliness.

zZGLZW3PMhaV8zPQ5UN6Vg.text: If you don't really feel like standing in the 30 minute line to get your coffee at monmouth next door, Rabot Estate does serve up a coffee worth waiting its 6 minutes for. And don't miss out on the chocolate, get a whole bar and devour. it is GOOD!

zHRId8AQsHrvPyd7B-C9kw.text: This review is based on my cafe experience. I have heard mixed opinions about their restaurant dishes but i never tried their main dishes myself so i cant really judge them on that.The Rabot Estate is in a great location (away from the noise of the main street) with a very enticing open front design. The only disadvantage of their design is that it can get a bit cold if you sit at the front tables during the winter.I have tried their normal hot chocolate, salted hot chocolate, coffee chocolate(mocha) and all of them are exceptional. I have also tried their chilli hot chocolate but i found the amount of chilli shadowing the great chocolate so i wont be taking that again.Of course If you visit you must also treat yourself to the amazing crepes they make (both with dark & milk chocolate) and also try the brownies.I heard they now opened a terrace so i will definitely going back during the summer to check it out & try the savory dishes.

0YJMzYUnwRUXBIQafcjdUg.text: I've passed by Rabot many times when going through the market yet never went in until last night.  From the outside, it looks like a nice wine bar (and it is) - but what I didn't know was there's a restaurant upstairs.  I definitely would be interested in going there for dinner, since I had a lovely experience at the bar.  For a Thursday night, the place was busy, but we were able to secure a table right away, which was really nice.  I was there on a date and it seemed like the perfect ambiance for that - it was busy but not too loud and the music wasn't overwhelming - you could easily have a conversation.  The wine can be a bit pricey, but nothing out of the ordinary, given the stellar location.  The service was excellent - helpful and attentive.  I would absolutely recommend this place and will be back again in the near future.

ozl4FTpblG7Z1mYateCsrw.text: Chocolate heaven. I tried the chocolate and salty caramel which was dreamy and divine. I had the chili hot choco beverage which was spicy but not over the top, though it was very rich. What a nice spot to get out of the cold! And also inexpensive and with a restaurant upstairs. Very nice decor.

JaL4Ea6QDIswKQDh27aNuw.text: We shared a burger and a pork 5 ways dish... Both were amazing with a bottle of wine over looking the market.

JgplRcPpgZm9cXKgWs028w.text: The rabot made chocolate is really good! Tried the velvet beans, pricey but totally worth as a treat to your taste buds :-)

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. The store

htnfHtC7ergwtlHuuZVagQ.text: Salted Caramel Drinking Chocolate is happiness in a mug. Not too sweet and with a hint of salt.

KLPIw5-9NYfb2aTiVVFrWQ.text: If you're into chocolate or maybe just want to gift it to someone special, you can't go wrong with this place.  Even as crowded as this place got during the farmer's market, they were more than happy to open a new package for tasting.  I'm a dark chocolate lover and finding the variety and percentage of cocoa in each bark was hard to stick with just one choice.  You can't help, but to want to buy everything.  I say the prices are reasonable for the quality, but after a few barks the ££ starts adding up.The service is as sweet as the chocolate you can buy.

NE1QLgukf8Bs7M_sNiz_dQ.text: Freezing bar, cold food, but good drinks selection!Great service from the main guy - he was really friendly, chatty and was quick to take order for drinks. My friend and I then got a bit peckish and ordered sweet potato ribbons, french fries with chocolate aioli, crispy duck confit potato cake and yorkshire pudding filled with rare-seared parkin-spiced beef, white chocolate mash.The plates were cold, and I had a couple of mouthfuls of the yorkshire pudding before wondering whether this place was so trendy that cold yorkshire puddings were intentional!  I complained and then 10 minutes later a second was sent - this time, the plate was hot but the food was not! I would recommend coming here for a few drinks (keep your coat on though as there was quite the draught all evening) but head to somewhere like Elliott's nearby for food instead.

xlOXhrlzNRsEyWp46IZoWg.text: Mmm.. I reserve to myself the right to edit the review at a second test.Following our event, we had dinner at Rabot 1745, and I was really looking forward to test some of their dishes.Following the advise from the maitre chocolatier, I chose the curry fish (cod) in chocolate nibs and yorkshire pudding topped with beef and chocolate gravy. Sounds delicious and difficult!First the starter, yorkshire pudding. Was it good? Yes it was, really. Nicely presented, flavorful and just well made, an optimal start The pudding was well made, while the beef is rare as written in the menu, and the chocolate gravy gives you that nice touch that tingles the back of your mouth and makes everything delicious. An optimal start.The cod. Now here comes the bad stuff. Ok I was unconvinced by the idea of the dish, I couldn't figure out how to put together cocoa with a fish curry without covering one flavor with the other, but because of the suggestion by the nice lady who led the chocolate lesson I went for it anyway. And the result was just as I expected: there is definitely too much curry inside the dish, which is ok if you are eating at a south indian restaurant and you are having a general fish curry, but here I want to have something a bit more raffinate on my dish, especially if you want to put together spicy and bitter tastes with white fish... I'm really sorry as I loved the place and the starter, but that main is a wrong step. The chips coming as a side were not great either, a bit soft. The sauces with chips were a bit too fat and buttery. I mean the whole could esasily be improved, for example if you leave the skin on the potatoes then you acquire a bit more of taste you need in order to go with the chocolate aioli, I mean it's not difficult, just think a bit about the dishes before you put them on the menu!In the end, I will try again this place as I think it's natural spot would be the lamb and the beef, hence I will update my review there, where it can gets a ±1!

vaATGSswjwQhDhwJZTBZ_Q.text: Thought because everything is cacao it would be unhealthy, but they actually make an effort to make very good food with just a light cacao touch.

bp9osM5ldff0LS6TPBsAhQ.text: Went for dessert and a drink celebrate anniversary with my partner, which wasa brilliant decision.The staff were casual but professional and the chocolate dishes are nothing short of amazing!

-Z5J5nnEtVDCpZRHuVxq0g.text: I popped into Rabot Estate a few weeks back with a group of Yelpers, when we were all in need of a jolt before starting an exploration of Borough Market. It was quite a queue, and the menu was a bit overwhelming, but I was pretty desperately in need of caffeine, so I stuck it out.I ordered a mocha, and stood in line to pay before realizing I had never said what size I wanted. Then I realized that Rabot Estate only does one size of coffee. This is kind of a neat idea, because it makes things a lot simpler, but it's also tough because it takes away my choice in exactly how much of a caffeine overdose I want.The mocha itself was pretty good, though probably not worth the money I paid for it, since I didn't know what size I ordered when I paid. The place is funky and cool, and would be great to tuck in on a cold winter day.

astTKMppWXUG78dwFvgS1g.text: Wonderful chocolate and chocolate concoctions... at a price.That said, the price is worth it, the shop's chocolates are amazing and they have samplings while you shop. I purchased the dark chocolate infused with caramel bits and it was wonderful. I also purchased their milk chocolate for a friend here that doesn't like dark chocolate (I knooow, right?!), and it was the best milk chocolate I've ever had...and I'm not a huge fan of milk chocolate. At 50% cacao, it wasn't overly sweet like your average milk chocolate, but just right.The cafe has a creative menu of savory and sweet items infused with chocolate. The 70% cocoa drinking chocolate w/ chili was outstanding, it really hit the spot on such a chilly  day in London! I almost came back and ordered a second.If you are visiting Borough Market, this shop is definitely worth a stop in.

QlMz2jBul610Ap-F-DQT0w.text: Went to the restaurant for brunch, sat in the very nice outside balcony seating area where they have heaters and blankets. I had the chocolate granola served with milk and maple syrup and it was delicious! It was a small portion that was quite expensive but you could tell the ingredients are high quality. Also had the peppermint and cocoa tea infusion which was perfect, much better than the disappointing hot chocolate that I've had previously at Rabot.The only downside was slow service- it took over 30 minutes to get a bowl of granola. Still, I will be visiting again.Concerning what is on offer downstairs in the cafe, I tried the chocolate brownie. Oh my goodness, it was a chocoholics dream. Massive chunk of gooey brownie packed with smooth chocolate lumps and with a drizzle of chocolate on top. Absolutely perfect. The hot chocolate, on the other hand, was a disappointment, could barely detect any chocolate in there at all, only frothy milk.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate granola with soya milk and maple syrup

CxLhh9Mq6kD3a4mSUlujFg.text: Expensive, but excellent.Dark chocolate with a splash of milk. It's not bitter, but definitely still dark.Infused with chili - you eat it and can't really taste the chili at first. But then your mouth and throw get warmer. it's not too hot, just right.Infused with caramel - laced with these tiny pieces of caramel that crunch in your mouth. Just enough to get a hint of the caramel without overwhelming the chocolateBest part is, I got them discounted because they were close (within a few weeks) to the expiry date.

9F7I0K72KJLAgnPCfsabSQ.text: Like the mothership calling me home the Rabot Estate suddenly caught my attention while I was on my way out of Borough Market. The smell of fresh coffee wafted over and the sight of chocolate sealed the deal. Although a lover of the smell of coffee I've never really been one for the taste so I opted for a hot choc while my sister went for the latte. Wow, it was like a cup of melted chocolate, very rich but not too sweet. Perfection! I took a little wander around the store taking in the many slabs of chocolate ranging in flavours and cacao levels. They sell cacao nibs, now I'm not 100% sure what these are but it seemed to excite and please a group who had wandered in and from looking at previous reviews it looks as though they are popular in baking. They sell a chocolate cookbook too! I didn't purchase any choc on this occasion as I felt fatty enough from the hot chocolate and huge bratwurst I'd had in Borough Market but I do plan to return to try their 50% milk chocolate recommended by Tristan J and gingerbread-infused chocolate buttons. Mmm...some things are just worth being fat for!

C8BCwuvN76nkFjAIa5BgfA.text: Fresh Monmouth Coffee, Super Pancakes and a great selection of Chocolate from St Lucia! What more do you want? The place was a little quiet on my visit (other than some Caribbean Music). This meant I got a walk through of the store from one of the friendly members of staff; offered a sample of Chili Hot Chocolate, and then tried a Sweet Cocoa Crepe. The Crepe was superb, the batter infused with chocolate before being stuffed with a hazelnut chocolate sauce! Yummy. Apparently The Rabot Estate Cocoa Plantation in St Lucia is owned by Hotel Chocolat. The store in Borough Market is essentially a Hotel Chocolat outlet that also serves sweet snacks and drinks. Which is why you will find many Hotel Chocolat products also on offer here. I guess the rustic plantation feel of the place is more likely to appeal to a Borough Market audience, hence the rebrand for this outlet.

b3QDRkFboWaBqucSBRd4_w.text: Chocolate-eating tends to be a decadent experience. You get your Swiss/Belgian/insert-other-European-country-here chocolate at a chocolatier's poncy shop in dainty, delicate portions. And you nibble and savour it with relish, the great cacao connoisseur that you are. But where does that chocolate come from?Hot countries. Countries close to the Equator. That is to say, countries that are not in Europe. And how do they eat chocolate in these countries? Well, I can only imagine they eat it in large, broken slabs if the chocolate at Rabot Estate - the London shop of this West-Indies-based cacao plantation - is anything to go by.I condone eating chocolate by the slab.And the café onsite seems the ideal place to get a hot chocolate or a mocha latte (if you're that way inclined).

Mjb8HWO1txC7eJEwBh4gEg.text: This is review for their coffee... I always feel bad leaving 2 stars but this is a coffee/chocolate cafe and the coffee just wasn't very good. The foam was cold so I took a massive sip and the coffee was really unbelievable hot and the beans were burnt. The chocolate was ok but I guess I have been spoilt along the way and I think having burnt bean coffee and the chocolate together they didn't really compliment each other. Also I went to the wrong counter wasn't really spoken to all that nicely. Maybe the waitress needs a little holiday. On a positive note, the coffee part of the shop is nice and cosy and has a lot of places for singles or couples to sit and enjoy the atmosphere and people watch. Maybe check out their hot chocolates? Surely..?

Enkjw2ga9TiAI1Ci0vscnQ.text: Okay maybe I'm being a bit overzealous with the stars here, but I don't care.  A few weeks ago I was looking for cake recipes for my partner's birthday, and I found one that looked great!  Chocolate cake with white chocolate ganache.  The white chocolate ganache used cream that you infuse with cacao nibs, and while it seemed a bit complicated, it also sounded delicious.  Great!  One problem.  I couldn't find nibs anywhere.  Seriously.  I went everywhere.  I found someone online, but it wasn't in enough time to get them in time for the birthday.  As an American transplant in the UK, it is a bit frustrating when attempting to find things that are commonplace in the US (unsweetened baking chocolate and nibs are two examples) when they are practically impossible to find in the UK.  I mean the cultures can't be THAT different can they?  Apparently so.  I had to change plans and bake a different chocolate cake (which called for unsweetened chocolate, and the best I could find was 90%... annoying).  Anyway, we were at the borough market the other day (picking up wine I believe because one of the wine merchants has amazing Sauternes), and we passed Rabot Estate.  On a whim, I ducked in, went up to someone and asked, "Hey do you sell cacao nibs?  Not the chocolate covered ones, just the nibs?"  Done and done.  They sell them by the espresso cupful.  For only two pounds a cupful.  I bought two for future use.  I also bought some chocolate bark with chili flakes which was absolutely delicious.  Not too spicy.  Anyway, they get 5/5 just for having cacao nibs.  I may be throwing stars around willy-nilly, but when it comes to finding the rare (in the UK) ingredients I need for baking, I don't take things lightly.  I'm planning a second birthday for myself this year just to make this cake.

o1DO4Vwu3qBJANuV4w72hA.text: London Bridge is simply one of my go/to places in London. It's situated on the modern yet hip south bank, very central and close enough to the city. Visiting Borough Market is just one of the many amazing places that makes food culture in London so extraordinary. The mix of appreciation of old and new, local and exotic and the amazing variety of cuisines from around the world. Though the restaurants on the edge of famous market are well catered to fit the requirements for locals and tourists. Fast service, efficient reception and professional manner. This certainly happened when I was claiming my gift voucher for afternoon tea at Rabbot 1745 with my other half. In corporation with Hotel Chocolate, the restaurants knowledgeable chocolate theme and specialisation in all things cocoa and chocolate was well in the spirit. The ambience with a small chocolate shop with cocoa and chocolate infused oils, pasta, confectioners and pastries with the warm pine-wood interior and brass details made the atmosphere very pleasant. Their selection of chocolate drinks and foods was mind-staggering. The hip wood stools and playful wooden patchwork in the wall of the restaurant makes it a perfect location for late lunch in a winter afternoon. In the middle of the busy bustle of London. A perfect place to meet a friend before heading grocery shopping and home. I have a weakness for white hot chocolates, and my boyfriend ordered the nutmeg hot chocolate. We received savoury sandwiches with chucked, ham, salmon and cucumber fillings. The scone don the second layer had a good airy consistency. The top layer of sweets were moderately nice, though I'd recommend they have a better selection of various chocolate pastries. As most of them had dark chocolate and nuts. Seeing how much of a chocolate mouse I am myself, this was never an issue. Though for the venue to portray their best selection of the varieties of chocolate, I'd say they should have included this on their sweet section for afternoon tea. As for some dark chocolate can be bitter. Overall an amazing place. The best for large warm hot chocolates. And for those chocolate lovers who want a bit more of an elaborate experience with an urban twist. And for those Heath enthusiasts wanting to go all out on their chest day.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. The real deal
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Our amazing hot chocolate drinks!

JJWFcKEZCPzhvvrkDNi4-A.text: We came here after reading about this restaurant in the evening paper and being in the area.  It was described as 'contemporary dishes influenced by the West Indies and Britain, with the savoury richness of cacao used as a subtle garnish, infusion and spice throughout'.  "Great' we thought "a Caribbean restaurant near where we are going for drinks, let's go".  We managed to get a table booked for later on that night which, I thought remarkable given it was a sunny Friday evening after all!There is a small bar downstairs with a chocolate shop next door.  This restaurant is associated with Hotel Chocolat although you would not know this as it is rebranded to the restaurant.Upstairs there is another bar and the restaurant on the terrace overlooking Borough Market.  We were shown out little table and presented with the menus. They had very faint music in the background from a small speaker system.  You had to really tune in to hear it.  There was 'Caribbean' music in the modern sense.  To give the correct atmosphere, they could do with selecting more traditional music for the influence they were after.Whilst there was a good selection of foods to select from, we could not help wondering where the influence from the West Indies came into it more than the use of the Cacao bean with many of the dishes.We ordered salmon cakes and flat bread for starter.  The waitress came back to say sorry the salmon we ordered was not available but she had noted the wrong dish so we still got the cakes.  They were nothing remarkable, potato pieces could have been cooked a little further.  The dips with the flat bread were nice although could have skipped the chocolate one for a starter.  Although I love chocolate and almost a pudding person dream to have chocolate for starter, I really want to stick with savoury or sweet not mix.I ordered fish for main (the original fish on the menu was not available so they had a replacement).  This was nice served with a pumpkin mash.  The flavours worked well together and the fish nicely cooked.Now for dessert.....dessert please....??? Anyone??  We waited for a good while then had to request the dessert menu.  Some yummy choices, with, of course the chocolate to accompany them.  Should be noted, this isn't the sweet manufactured chocolate many will know and love, but more the pure type so it can be a little bitter which may not be to everyones taste.I had sticky toffee pudding (that will be the British influence) which was OK.  I have had better I think.Service could have been a little better esp. as it wasn't that busy.  We poured our own wine most of the time with the waiters failing to top us up.The toilets seem to be in a secret door by the bar (which was busy so clearly a favourite here) and they are unisex.....! hmmm.They don't mention it but as I am a Hotel Chocolat member, I asked about their connection.  Then they let me know that you get 5% off the bill as a member just flash your card.  5% isn't very much in the grand scheme of things but something is better than nothing I suppose.All in all it was OK here. I think the bar is more popular than the restaurant at this time but, I would come back if I was in the area and needed food and drink.  Definitely feel the 'West Indian' influence needed to be stronger. It doesn't have to be all Jerk this and Jerk that but there is more they could do with flavours and ingredients to pull this out more.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Sticky toffee pudding
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Dessert Menu
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Fish with Pumpkin Mash

bgmDUik0tzvyXQILjHwoGw.text: This was a quick visit while visiting Borough Market. I just came here for tea to go. Small place. Good customer service and prices were very decent.

z8pReqYhbY1ZBgB0q-mPhg.text: Great place next to borough market.  One of those places where it is constantly a good level of busy. Nice wooden decor and the staff are friendly. The brownies are perfection and the coffee was good. Perfect for a sunny day or to escape the rain.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

kzQwCthkygyj0T4mxNYgiQ.text: Starting with the food first, they were doing a deal of £17.45 for two courses during weekdays. The venison starter had a nice combination of flavour tho slightly towards the blend side.The sea bass and sweet potato main had really fresh fish and nice sweet potato inside, however the other side - spinach was completely off. It must be soaked in lemon juice and cacao overnight because it was so sour and too much cacao made my lips very numb. Both me and my friend tried the dish and we both agreed this dish was on the edge of being returned to the kitchen if it wasn't because fish being nice. The pork selection with cacao gravy had very nice gravy, flavour has a new twist but not overpowering. However the pork meat was disappointing. Two out of three pieces were super dry. We also ordered moose selection as dessert. It has grounded cacao bits on the surface which gives it a nice lift of flavour. I'd recommend this dish. The restaurant has a nice atmosphere, staffs were friendly and fast. I got to try full 3-course with a taste of 2 different mains as £17.45 each with a friend. However judging by the quality of food, I definitely wouldn't pay more than £17 for a 3-course at this restaurant. Hope this helps!

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Venison starter, sea bass and sweet potato main and the other main in the background is pork selection with cacao gravy sauce

lIfvC9ADg2Duqqt-gkcU0Q.text: One of those places I'd generally avoid solely on how it looks from the outside and where it is. However I was pleasantly surprised by Rabot 1745. The food was excellent, well presented from an interesting menu. The cocoa thing does get a little bit over the top but it works as a gimmick and the flavours it generates are generally well placed.The service is good, the matire d was a little overbearing but our waitress was lovely. Decent prices and the outdoor terrace is a really unique position above Borough Market. Nice spot.

XU3H3yNRturDhKPsu2tNog.text: Yes, I went to a chocolate-centric restaurant for a burger... And I bloody loved it!Tucked just down the side of Borough Market, Rabot is a chocolate lover's paradise. But as I found out, chocolate isn't all they do well.I grabbed a late lunch with a client, and was treated to a lusciously meaty pattie, super-tasty bacon, cheese, and a creole relish, perilously wedged between two toasted halves of a (brioche?) bun with chocolate sprinkles.The accompanying side of chips were a bit salty, but my god that burger! Price was quite high, but ultimately worth it. 2 burgers and a couple of drinks came to just shy of £50.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate chip sprinkles!
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

lwaWTfWB-uNWrymfTGRjtA.text: This review is actually 3.5 stars - we visited Rabot on a Friday night for a 4 people dinner. Each one of us tried a main and dessert so we had a decent variety to try. Desserts (lava cake, cheesecake, mousse and roasted fig) were the highlight of our meal, the mains were presented very well but lacked a bit flavor and the service was just plain bad. I think I will be back for the bar area and desserts/hot chocolate.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Photo called "Endless wait for anyone to come and take our orders"

lJEPiVAO1n87KuY4SyvVmw.text: After having dinner at the Wright Brothers, we stopped in for dessert. Who can say no to chocolate desserts? I had the molten lava cake. It was good and the molten center was delish. However, I found the cake portion to be incredibly dry as if it was in the oven too long. There also ice cream on the side. The ice cream was the definite highlight! It was housemade and infused with cocoa nibs. Next time, I would skip the molten lava cake and just get the ice cream.They have a great selection of bottles or half bottles of wine. However, as a glass there is only one choice for red, white, or sparkling.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

0PI20qEcDB2DTNsn6_PVLA.text: Rabot 1745 is part of Hotel Chocolate. The restaurant was lovely, loved the atmosphere, the lighting and the size. Reminded me a bit of a French ski lodge the interior also when you go to the bathroom you are surrounded amongst wooden walls with the noise of forest creatures before finding the door to the toilet. The staff are happy and very helpful. Food that we had me a beef pudding and my husband and hamburger was good size portions, hot and tasty. The chocolate that was used partially in our food was different and really did give our food a bit of a twist. I would deff eat at Rabot again especially is wanting a nice romantic meal as the lighting and the size of the restaurant is quaint. Just lovely.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Suet pudding in the restaurant of Rabot 1745
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Dessert in cafe of Rabot 1745

cTv2LYBQmtI_6D9CYevOeA.text: Came across this place randomly when looking for a place to eat with a friend one evening and we were impressed! We sat on the balcony which is inside the market. It was evening so everything was closed but I presume in the daytime this is a great spot to people watch. We went to start with a cocktail and they have a good list of unusual choices, however none took my fancy so I went for wine. For food, I had the aubergine curry which was good. Not very spicy and not a huge portion but nice fresh flavours. The best thing however was their signature-the molten chocolate pudding! Definitely have this if you go! Perfectly cooked and I would return for this alone!

Y_aFScQq_LYD7GKfSUX1ng.text: Duck and Chocolate.  I repeat, DUCK and CHOCOLATE.On my walk through Borough Market a day earlier, I spotted this store and cafe and, having already eaten, I vowed to come back.  And so I did.I had one of the savory CACAO WRAPS with confit duck from Marché du Quartier, dried cherries, Rabot 66% dark chocolate, coriander, cacao nibs and crème fraiche.  My friend tried one of the sweet ones with Maldon sea salt caramel and cacao whipped cream.  We both loved our wraps!  I didn't think duck and chocolate would go well together and I was wrong.  The dark chocolate is key.  I hope to find a similar crepe back home in the States!By the way, these wraps are light enough that you can eat some more elsewhere if you want to try more yummy items from other vendors.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Cacao Wrap w Maldon Sea Salt Caramel and Cacao Whipped Cream
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Cacao Wrap w Maldon Sea Salt Caramel and Cacao Whipped Cream

ds-IfJvAZF4jeEH0k_Z2rQ.text: I first came to Rabot on a rainy night at close so I decided to come later on. I went in with a couple friends--the environment was very relaxed and the baristas were friendly. I originally came in wanting a latte with a shot of salted caramel vodka. However, since they are known for their chocolate, I decided to order a creamy hot chocolate with the shot of espresso and shot of salted caramel vodka. Overall, it was quite delicious and pretty unique because I don't know any place that adds alcohol to their cafe items in the states. The baristas were extremely friendly when my friends didn't like their drink and worked to make it more enjoyable for them. I overall enjoyed my experience here!

qSYDfiE_6_LBpP05IoIgtQ.text: I came here last year, and totally forgot about it, I was in the kitchen making dessert, but then I had an opportunity to try their food.As you walk in, you are greeted by the big chocolate machine, showing you from bean to bar, which is pretty amazeballs! It is the roasting and conching method which is shown. Then you see that luscious chocolate pouring - mmmmmmmmmmmmm!Hotel Chocolat is the only chocolate shop in the UK that shows this method to those who walk into their shop. At least this way you know what you are buying, and how its made. Why is it called hotel chocolat, and does it really have a hotel? It sure does, in the caribbean, St.Lucia where their beautiful beans are grown!As for Rabot, they use the chocolate in every aspect of their food and drink, cocoa bitter cocktails, its even used in a burger that they make, like a chocolate ketchup almost. I had their drinking chocolate with salted caramel - talk about rich, thick and gulpy!!! Was not drinkable, had to remove the lid and sort of use a spoon with it! But it was very nice with the gingerbread - as I love gingerbread, but I think a balance of milk and chocolate is needed!I also had their molten chocolate lava pudding made from the cacao bean here on site, Rabot ice cream - nib infused. Was delicious!! Chocolate oozed out of the lava cake, wasn't a heavy pudding - relatively light which was surprising, worked really well with the nib infused ice cream. The contrast of sweet and bitter, as cocoa nibs aren't sweet at all! I'd happily go back just for that.It's good they sell chocolate, although they don't really have much of a selection, if you are looking for a vast collection - maybe try strand, covent garden etc. Also strand branch sells vegan chocolate which is pretty good!!!

JdIHRe751uSpCKvtYmge3w.text: If you like chocolate and a chill atmosphere then this is your place. I had the basic hot chocolate with a shot of rum and chocolate whip cream.  Order the whip on the side.

HhqjKj3J-HKBkT_6ZXwW5w.text: Sitting in the corner of the terrace the entirety of Borough Market lies within your gaze. While this not always places you in the eye of the waitstaff, it more than makes up for the slight waits for their attention with its atmosphere. What's more is that this is enjoyable in winter too, as blankets are provided if you choose to sit on the terrace.The menu at Rabot 1745 is varied, with one element ever-present: cacao - whether your chicken is covered in a cocoa-rub, or cacao beans are sprinkled on top of your burger's brioche bun, the nod to the chocolatey heritage of the restaurant operated by the chain that owns Hotel Chocolat can be as subtle or loud in flavour, depending on your choice. As such no meal is ever off-putting in taste, and certainly not in appearance. With hot chocolate available as a pre-meal beverage, and great variety in cocktails there's something to whet your whistle at all times too, with plenty of non-dairy options if you were so inclined.

h6sUNxMGeMPEauvj_IsbmA.text: Hmmm I think this is a 2.5 rounded up to 3 review. The extra half a star is a bonus for trying to do something different and for the fantastic service from our server, MontyRabot have been spreading the gospel of good high end chocolate through their Hotel Chocolat chain. Their flagship shop has been in Borough Market for years but this has recently moved a short distance to new premisesThe ground floor still houses the retail shop and cafe but upstairs, you'll find their brand new restaurant. I was luck to be invited along by a friend in the first week that they were openThe restaurant is classy and well deorated. When we sat down, we found a little bowl of beans at each place setting. Being Yelpers, we were a little impatient and had a little nibble - ooh, very bitterBefore too long, Monty came along and seeing the evidence on trhe table, asked if we had enjoyed the cocoa beans. We confessed that they had been a little bitter. She then explained that the roasted beans weren't meant to be eaten whole. She taught us how to break open the shell, which is the bitter part, thereby revealing the inner cacao nibShe then gave us a little lesson about the origin of chocolate and how cacao nibs are savoury and it only turns into chocolate with the addition of sugar. Used in its natural state, cacao is a savoury product, almost tasteless but with a crunchThe USP of Rabot 1745 is that every dish on the menu contains cacao in some form. Between the 6 of us, we managed to try a good range of the dishes on the menuMy starter of fish carpaccio was nice but I'm not sure the few bits of crunchy cocoa nib added anything extra to the dish. That was the general concensus of the group - nice starters in flavour but the cocoa didn't really add anythingI was lucky in getting the best of main courses - a slow cooked piece of lamb, whcih was yummy. Unfortunately, my dining companions weren't as lucky. The other dishes, especially the sauces, lacked punchHowever, the cacao came alive in the desserts. A trio opf chocolate mousses showcased the different flavours of cocoa beans from different parts of the world - my favourite was the fruity Vietnamese. The chocolate tasting plate was also fun, giving a real variety of chocolate products including a 100% cocoa stick, which technically isn't chocolate as you need to add a minimum of 4% sugar to cacao to call it chocolateI take my hat off to the kitchen - the lovely plating reveals an ambition in the kitchen but I can't help feeling that using cacao in every dish is currently a bit of a gimmick. I can understand why Rabot wanted this USP but in many dishes, it served as a distraction and ultimate disappointment when it didn't really add anything to the dish. I'm not sure how they can solve this issue but perhaps to add dishes like Mexican mole, which does use chocolate to add depth to the sauce, may be a startA nice bonus was a card for a 20% discount in the retail store to be used that same eveningI wish them luck in their endeavour as I admire their bravery in trying to do something different

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Duck
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

Ci7unMwWwED3rfXSpbnUDQ.text: So, Rabot 1745 is a combo restaurant/coffee shop. We escaped to the coffee shop from the very busy Borough Market across the road. The space is neatly designed to give a cozy feel and staff were pleasant. My husband and I both ordered the Coffee Chocolate which is the equivalent to a Mocha and it was delicious. It tasted so chocolately, unlike anything I have ever tasted before coffee-wise. The only negative is that they served this delicious drink in a white ceramic mug with no handle. It looked nice but it wasn't functional because the mug was hot hot hot causing us to wait for the coffee and mug to cool before we could sip down the liquid deliciousness. Also note that it looks like they recently opened a terrace which is probably cool.

pcSuwOu6w1ZzTGBcJVCteA.text: I have been to Rabot estate before but this time i saw the cafe with a restaurant and i loved it. I bought chilli Dark chocolate as am a big fan if it and i ordered a 70% Dark chili hot chocalate. It was very rich and i would say mild spicy( to me) in a good way. I luved it. The staff are very welcoming and nice and atmosphere is lovely for evening or even day time. You have to come here if u passed

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

QOvLNHdyv6KWHj1kVMJu-g.text: Great Cafe/Restaurant located just by Borough Market, owned by Hotel Chocolat, this is the place to go for a nice fresh chocolate or coffee and cake if you don't want to be with all the hustle and bustle of the market nearby, till service in place, then you find your seat, is always busy in there they also have a restaurant upstairs and an open area that overlooks the market.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

quhO6T4mtIcQTaO4Vs8LDg.text: Excellent mochas. Artisan chocolate. Did i mention excellent mochas? You can select the intensity of chocolate. The 70% chocolate mocha was perfect for me.Some locations do not serve drinks or food. This one does. Market is very busy on Saturdays. Worth the visit.

Rh0QJulabWBjLk7bdNpBUA.text: We happened upon this restaurant on a busy weekend evening, after finding just about everything else in the Borough Market area full with long waits. We were just so grateful to get a table, we didn't know we were in for such a fantastic experience. We were seated on the rooftop, which even on a chilly March evening was nice and cozy with heaters. This would be a great spot to eat lunch while the market is bustling!The food was some of the best we had in London. I'm sure everything would have been great, but our server was super confident in his recommendations when we asked "this or that" while ordering, and everything we ordered was fantastic. Service when we were first seated was a little slow (seemed to be a bit of confusion over who was serving our table) but once that was straightened out the service (by all) was warm and attentive.Rabot 1745 is at the top of my recommendation list for anybody visiting London!

qG5CesF5wgDYgNGkoS9vrA.text: Ok, so I ended up here my accident. My friends and I were originally supposed to go to a Padella, then tried to go somewhere else only to find it was closed, and thus lost our place in the ever-growing queue. Why do restaurants in the always-busy Borough Market close?? In any case, clearly Rabot has realised this issue because they were open at the awkward time of 4:30 pm when we wanted an early dinner. I've known about the restaurant because of the Hotel Chocolat brand, but it never really occurred to me that I would want to eat a full meal of chocolate-inspired dishes. If you don't spend too much time overthinking it, it's not like everything tastes like chocolate - they just try to use various derivatives of the cocoa bean. We sat outside on the terrace, where you can hear what's going on downstairs at the market, and also feel the trains going by every now and then. None of the mains spoke to me, so I ordered two starters - the pulled pork piton and a fried fish dish. They were both good, but very small, and served in very large plates. I'd say that Rabot styles itself in the more fine dining end of the spectrum. My friends got the hake, burger, and chicken mains, and I'd say they were all small except for the burger. Then again, I'm not sure how the burger fits in with the whole fine dining idea. I don't think I'd see myself coming back, except for the fact that they happened to serve food when not many other places did.

rgsDIyVP7CKYA6jhC_bb2g.text: Right outside the Borough Market, a lovely, chocolatey haven from the cold. Try the hot chocolate! Everything is a tad expensive for me but so so worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

r9cQDEzscr2JBUpFc4kSDg.text: If you fancy yourself a chocolate connoisseur and a Snickers bar just won't do, you need to bring yourself to this slightly-pretentious chocolate shop/ restaurant/ cafe.I would say it's like the Max Brenner of London- think Willy Wonka's Chocolate Factory for adults. They use only the most premium chocolate and ingredients in their drinks and food, and almost everything is chocolate-inspired, yet not necessarily sweet.The sweetness of their drinks is not overpowering, and the notes of whatever is in them come across perfectly-balanced; if it's a hazelnut latte, you can really taste the hazelnut without all the sugar, and if it's the spiced chocolate, you can really taste those spices. Some like the salted caramel are a bit sugary, but no less delicious, and if you have a chance to come back, always give their seasonal drinks a try. The Spooky Boo with salted caramel, spiced pumpkin, cocoa, and super-thick whipped cream during the Fall is amazing!They also have a cool little section where you can take away some packaged chocolate and boozy chocolate-inspired drinks from Hotel Chocolat that I guarantee are among the highest quality out there.If you decide to dine in their actual restaurant upstairs, get ready to shell out some serious dough for some dangerously-delicious cuisine. Yes, there is still chocolate, (or at least cacao), in most of their dishes, but it is there more to bring out the essence of whatever you're eating rather than overpower it. The Bois Bondais was perhaps my favorite meal there, as the chicken and vegetables are cooked to perfection and the sauce really serves to bring everything together with a simple, yet beautiful, presentation, to boot.The cocktails, are really something else. My absolute favorite is the Salted Caramel Soother made with a Salted Caramel vodka from Hotel Chocolat and sprinkled with crushed cacao bits for a bit of a crunch. It may be one of the more perfectly-balanced cocktails you will ever have in your life. They also serve chocolate-infused beers and fruity wines that just happen to be on the sweeter side.Oh, and did I mention that for an extra £1.50 you can spike any of your coffees or hot chocolate drinks here with salted caramel vodka, even during the day? Yeah.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. 9-Hour Cacao Braised Shin of Beef
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Caramelized Banana Cheesecake with Peanut Ice Cream
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Chevre Soup with Cacao Nib Buttered Toast

05TtgibcN2eSFNbl01t4qA.text: We came for a decadent dessert and cocktail... What we got was shoddy service, average cocktails and a dessert we didn't order.I was so unimpressed this time round and so very glad we had eaten salads from M&S before we came for dessert.I had bought 2 Timeout vouchers for the famous BAFTA award dessert, which was basically chocolate upon chocolate, and cocktail for £15 (the dessert itself it just shy of this) and turned up at 9pm on a Thursday to enjoy after the cinema. The voucher states explicitly not to book sooo we didn't. It was fine anyways as there was plenty of room. We were seated. Our vouchers were taken. Our cocktails were ordered. We were then told the dessert would take an hour to prepare as they had stopped making them each day as they took so long. Also to be told that we should have rung ahead to let them know we were coming.... So rude. Instead of waiting we could order the desserts from their menu (£8-10). Unfortunately we weren't planning on returning to the area before the vouchers ran out, and I definitely wasn't waiting an hour to be served dessert so we instead picked our dessert from the normal menu. These came out with the cocktails after 10/15 minutes. We opted for the White chocolate cheesecake and the chocolate lava cake. Neither were anything special. The cocktails were also okkkk but by then I just wanted to drink up and go home :(All in all a bad experience especially after I was so looking forward to going!

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

-mF2D4HxRp6TjNH4wwMMVw.text: We stopped here for a coffee and hot chocolate break. The coffee was good but did not compare to the hot chocolate which was excellent and decadent. This place is highly recommended for hot chocolate fans.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

Qxie5gTQ6mxtgNXbwjUQPw.text: Oh dear, I am so far behind with my Yelp reviews.  It's been a good few weeks since I visited Rabot 1745.  I mainly chose it because it was the only cafe with a couple of seats while all other establishments had people spilling out onto the street.  Don't let this put you off, it is a truly lovely place.I've only just read the other reviews, and it all makes sense now.  I couldn't quite figure our why the drinks menu was dominated by hot chocolate rather than coffee - it definitely doesn't have a chocolate chain store feel to it (I love Hotel Chocolat, don't get me wrong!).  Nothing beats seeing the world pass by over a glass of bubbly - Rabot 1745 has class.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

GesgWF3CxI1xieGdluTA_w.text: Positives:-Convenient location in Borough market.-Heated terrace area.-Interesting menu.Negatives:- very long wait time and slow service.Rabbit has been on my list of places to try for a year now, so I was really looking to indulging. Unfortunately, my experience started a little wobbly as I was given a Diet Coke in a dirty glass. The residue from some kind of milky chocolate drink was still clinging to sides and to my horror, did not start floating to the surface of MY drink until I'd drunk half of it. The waitress quickly brought me a new one but wasn't particularly apologetic.Starters arrived in good time (bearing in mind we only ordered one to share between us, the French onion soup)but we waited an hour for our main meal to arrive. This is despite the restaurant only running at 50-60% capacity.The robot burger was delicious and the fries were super crispy but I didn't manage to eat much as we only had 18 minutes to cram it all in, thanks to the long wait time and a show to get to in another location.The Cote Du Rhone wine was excellent but again, I couldn't finish an entire carafe of wine in the 18 minutes we had left. Another member of staff did come over to speak to us and very kindly apologised for the long wait time. He also took the cost of the drinks off the menu, which was nice but I'd rather just have a clean glass for my drink and enough time to finish my meal in the future, haha!Hopefully, I'll be back to try this place again the future.If I do, you can look forward to an update on the service!

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Rabot burger
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Cocoa nib Mac and cheese
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. French onion soup

2QCf1oycXk2F1r__zoJpVA.text: Amazing Chocolate Afternoon Tea, and greeted with a glass of prosecco when using a voucher deal, extremely good value!  It is such fun trying all the different mini sandwiches, scones, shortbread and cakes, all with chocolate themes, and lovely hot chocolate with rum or without, with nutmeg or cinnamon.  I really liked the cocoshel earl grey sobert.The service was a bit hit and miss and they were not even busy. Constantly getting orders wrong, why does he not just write it down instead of committing it to memory, might have helped! But all in all a lovely afternoon, catching up and making new friends in a lovely venue right in the heart of Borough Market, a little gem, which you can easily miss, as the stairs upstairs to the upper floor is round the back and a bit hidden!

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Cocoshel, earl grey sobert
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Champers!
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Afternoon -everything on menu plus champers and hot choc with rum!

7Hl0H-oHcS-Gf5b_Y4uOhw.text: I visited the ground level Rabot coffee shop last week and it is a fantastic little gem in the middle of bustling Borough Market.  This is definitely a place to go to if you like hot chocolate.  Well, who doesn't?  They have several different blends of chocolate and they mix a few versions during the day, so it is very fresh.  I got the basic hot chocolate.  It was amazing.  From what others told me it is like the kind of hot chocolate you get in South America.  Space is tight in there, especially on a weekend day, so I recommend getting your hot chocolate for take away.  As an aside, they seem to have a restaurant upstairs.

OiYZ-IjX4OIHSVBLnHj_nQ.text: Stopped in because my friend had been dying to try this place out, overall we both left here happy with our hot cocoas. We stayed and drank them in shop enjoying the hustle and bustle, also after we took a look around at all the decadent chocolate.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

kLN_oL1X0MDpLSLVEkqmhQ.text: Found another gem for great coffee, and this time with lovely chocolate as well which is an absolute bonus.Rabot, located basically right in the middle of borough market is a great place for a sip of casual coffee or hot choc. The coffee tasted great as you would expect for a 5 star review, so the surprise here is for the hot chocolate.We had the 'Made in Borough' hot chocolate, basically it's a 70% coco drink, and it was just superb!Definitely worth going if you are close by. Which I guess that's also my only complaint, it's not exactly a neighbourhood area, so they make you work for your coffee (travelling there).

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom

Q4NsI-l5BUxaiD25aqIutg.text: Great place to wind down after taking on the closely market bustling with people. The place is busy yet you can relax watching Folge wheeling and dealing.

M2A4fsmPAka44TLEnPDm_w.text: This place is owned by Hotel chocolate. It has a fine dining restaurant on the first floor and is a bar/ coffee shop/ chocolate shop on the ground floor. I have visited the restaurant years ago and loved the food (most dishes has coco bean as an ingredient, which I found interesting). Last weekend I had dessert and drinks on the ground floor after dinner. It offers the same dessert menu as the main restaurant and needless to say, the chocolate dessert there is top class! I had a chocolate and chestnut delice with black current sorbet, which I recommend to any chocolate lover. The cake is very rich and it goes very well with the sharp sorbet. Coffee is pretty nice too:)

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Molten chocolate lava pudding with nib ice cream
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Chocolate and chestnut delice with black current sorbet
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Coffee, hot chocolate and cocktails

5zKBQc2y6diaQLt54JWioQ.text: As a chocolatier, Rabot 1745 was pretty high on my list of places to visit in London. I only had one day there and wanted to make it count, so my partner booked us in for dinner here. This was, hands down, one of the most interesting food experiences I've ever had. Going into it, I was unsure of how well one could incorporate chocolate into savory dishes. I love food so much, but I'm not really a foodie in the traditional sense as I tend to steer clear of anything I find pretentious. Rabot 1745 does a really beautiful job at making something unique without making it annoyingly so. Sure, there's cacao in every dish, but it's so subtle that all it does is enhance the flavor of whatever you're eating. Sadly, I was so full that I did NOT get to try the dessert here. But it only gives me more to look forward to on my next visit!I would highly recommend the Yorkshire pudding stuffed with white chocolate mash & the burger. Be sure to make use of the cacao ketchup for your chips! If you're in the mood for something new, give this gorgeous place a try. Bonus: it's super romantic!

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Yorkshire pudding stuffed with white chocolate mash.
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Burger & almond & cacao roasted cauliflower.

_KJx8uG2MibfsWyWaGQ-FA.text: This little chocolate cafe is on my regular list. Who can't resist a chocolate. This is a very warm cafe and a great escape from the cold after walking around the market. I love their large mugs and can't go past their mocha. They also have a tempting pastry selection. I had the double choc muffin, it was moist and not overly sweet. It ticked all the boxes as can be picky when I cakes to cakes, being a home baker myself find a lot of store cake dry and crumbly. This was not. Defiantly a place I would return to met a friend or enjoy some me time on my days off. Interested I trying their upstairs dining for brunch. Also their salted caramel hot chocolate is on my list for next visit.

R4E9H2xMnUlux9YnfVAhmw.text: You have to come here for the chocolate afternoon tea, great value at £40 for two and as we used our voucher before March we got a glass of processco each included.Starting off with mini sandwiches including gin infused Salmon; they all have some chocolatey theme, scones and chocolate ganache, jam and cream (who chooses the jam - crazy).  This is followed by dessert of chocolate cheesecake and shortbread with chocolate. Meanwhile we managed to slurp 2 of their hot chocolates each; I had salted chocolate and white chocolate with nutmeg. After all of that I couldn't move! All delicious, service could have been a bit better but can't complain as it didn't cost us an extra penny.

photos.caption: Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Salted caramel hot chocolate
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Dessert
Photo of Rabot 1745 - London, United Kingdom. Sandwiches

aj8uMa5QIc2GcSUg7JZ35g.text: My friend and I went there for breakfast. Very poor customer service. Staff were unhelpful and my friend and I had to clear the table ourselves while staff stood around. The food was average and overpriced for what it was.

hiwZQskurP_1nb_Plz3Atw.text: Really good coffee and delicious chocolate. However, lots of people order hot chocolate. From what I saw, the hot coco comes with something that looks like chocolate whipped cream, so I'm definitely going to try it next time I'm there. P.s if you're more than one person split up. Let somebody find a seat and the other person stand online because the place is PACKED!
